conbody.p: Logical truth: A sentence is logically true iff it is not possible for it to be false.
Logical falsity: A sentence is logically false iff it is not possible for it to be true.
Logical Indeterminacy: A sentence is logically indeterminate iff it is nether logically true nor logically false.
Logical equivalency: Two sentences are logically equivalent iff it is not possible for one to be true and the other false.
A set of sentences is consistent iff all of the sentences in that set are true.
True sentences have a truth-value of T. This is distinct from “truth functionally true"
False sentences have a truth-value of F. This is distinct from “truth functionally false”
Sentences that are neither true nor false do not have a truth value, but this is not the same as sentences that are “truth functionally indeterminate”
The inability to know whether a sentence is T or F does not change that it is T or F
Every sentence that has a truth value is either logically true or logically false.
Not all sentences are either logically true or logically false.

For example: Joseph cared for the children of Heinrich. Heinrich's children were cared for by Joseph. It is not possible for one to be true while the other is false; we could replace one with the other and the meaning would not be changed.
Every sentence is identical with itself. This seems simple and obvious enough, but keep this in mind; it will be helpful later.
